instances.text: Course Subject Default CCP View Security Work Set
PSYC_V 488-C_002 - Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience (C)
RGST_V 400-201 - Advanced Seminar in the Study of Religion

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Course Description:
This seminar explores diverse forms of shamanism across the globe, looking cross-culturally at shamanism as religion and worldview, at shamanism expressive culture (e.g., stories, music, material culture), at the stigmatization of shamanism and its revitalization, and at appropriate forms for neoshamanic practice and shamanic tourism.
By the end of the course, students will have an increased understanding of Indigenous religious cultures, the way that settle concepts of religion have harmed Indigenous communities, and the process of colonization and cultural resurgence that happened withing the context of religious belief and practices. This course – in lines with best practices in Indigenous studies – will abide strictly by the distinct protocols of the cultures we are engaging with in the classroom, and not engage with restricted materials.

instances.text: RHSC_V 420-003 - Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology
RHSC_V 420-L03 - Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Understand the major similarities and differences between the Romance languages—including lesser-known varieties—by exploring five linguistics domains: phonetics and phonology, morphology, syntax and sociolinguistics.  
See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/rmst400/  

Language of Instruction: English 

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Title: "The Strongman, the Latin Lover, and other Italian Masculinities" | An overview of diverse Italian masculinities as they are represented in Italian literature and culture.  
ITAL 409 and RMST 459 are taught in the same classroom at the same time by the same instructor. All students must register in RMST 459. Both courses fulfill the literature requirement for the Faculty of Arts.

See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/RMST459     

Language of Instruction: English 

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Topic: Sociology of Friendship

Friends comprise one of the core components of our intimate and social lives. They improve levels of happiness and life satisfaction and provide support, services, and emotional and financial aid. They are also prone to individualizing pressures that contribute to loneliness and isolation with direct consequences for health and well-being and can contribute to inequality. Students in this seminar will explore themes of friendship from a sociological perspective by reading current empirical and theoretical work and engaging in projects that explore themes of friendship.

A survey of foundational and contemporary perspectives in cultural theory, their applications, and their new directions

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Read some of the most outstanding theatrical plays of the early modern period from a comparative perspective and explore the diverse ways that gender and sexuality are represented in Spanish, French, Italian, English and Novohispanic stages. Cross-listed with SPAN 502 
See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/SPAN495  

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:

Jan. 9

Feb. 6

Mar. 13

Apr. 3 and 10

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Note: There are 80 spaces in this course and 20 spaces on the waitlist. If you are unable to add yourself to the waitlist, it is full. When a space becomes available in the course, students from the waitlist will be offered a seat (in order of date added to the waitlist). Spaces on the waitlist may open so check back regularly for an open space. Adding to the waitlist does not guarantee admission to the course. SPPH does not maintain a back-up waitlist. Thank you for your interest.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
https://ubc-stat.github.io/stat-450/
THIS COURSE IS RESTRICTED TO 4TH YEAR STAT MAJORS/COMBINED MAJORS/COMBINED HONOURS STUDENTS. If you are not in a Statistics program but have taken STAT 306 and are comfortable with R please contact stat450@stat.ubc.ca about the possibility of taking the course. https://www.stat.ubc.ca/undergrad-registration-info-and-faqs
Please register in the waitlist if the course is full. Please note that capacity for STAT 450 is limited but we anticipate admitting some students from the waitlist. however please have a back up plan in case you cannot secure a seat in STAT 450.
